[21]Oh no. [15]No, that was pretty good. 
[16]"All we can get?" 
[17]You know what you're qonna do, Rodney. You're gonna reject this shitty contract. You're gonna play out your existihg shitty contract and go be a free agent next year and the hell with Arizona. This is us, and we determine our worth. You're a fine, proud, surviving, splendid black man. 
[18]I'm sorry what I said back there. 
[19]My husband believes in you.  We're gonna make it.  Bye bye Dorothy. 
[20]Why don't you be the first man in your family not to say that word? And then we'll let you live. 
[21]Now go kiss your daddy, quick. 
[22]-- so I go to see a so-called "black" film the other day -- -- honey, no more salt for you, I don't want you dehydrated for Monday Night Football.  Most important game of your career. 
[23]-- TWENTY minutes of coming attractions. All black films, all violent, I'm talking about brothers shooting brothers, Wesley Snipes with guns the size of our house, killing, blood flowing, cars crashing... blood blood blood blood. Is this all they think we want to see? Come on!  I enjoyed Shindler's List.  Give me a little credit, I mean hooo -- 
[24]Oh baby -- 
[25]Baby.  Baby.  Baby... 
[26]What does daddy say? 
[27]Boy, no s-h-i-t. 
[28]Can you be quiet? 
[29]Shut up!!! 
[30]Can't you be loyal to your brother who LOVES you?? Get out of my house! 
[31]I'm freakin out.  Oh God I'm -- 
[32]"Stay calm?"  I'm freakin... 
[33]My whole life is this family, Jerry. It doesn't work without him. 
[34]You ain't talking now, are you??? You're a silent motherfucker!
dialogues.LAUREL:
[1]Come on, I'm double-parked. 
[2]What about medical? 
[3]You are a single mother.  You have given up the right to be frivolous. 
[4]You know how much those Well Child exams cost -- 
[5]And that's just when he's well -- 
[6]He's in the living room asleep. 
[7]Sorry. 
[8]At eleven at night? 
[9]Dotty -- this is not "guy.". This is a "syndrome."  It's called Early Midlife, About-To-Marry, Hanging Onto The-Bottom-Rung Dear- God-Don't-Let-Me-Be-Alone, I'll- Call-My-Newly Long-suffering- Assistant-Without Medical-For- Company Syndrome.  And if, knowing all that, you still allow him to come over, more power to you. 
[10]Okay, but he better not be good looking! 
[11]You seem just the way I pictured you. I'm her disapproving sister Laurel. 
[12]I heard. 
[13]This guy would go home with a gardening tool right now if it showed interest. Wait.  Use the frosted glasses. 
[14]Look, here's some of that chicken with salsa too, I warmed it up -- 
[15]But you just gotta hear me out on one thing.  You're very responsible with Ray and you know it's not right for a little boy to hear some strange man's voice in the house. 
[16]Come on, let's get you another top -- 
[17]All I'm saying.  You don't have the luxury of falling for some drowning man.  Be practical.  Now. Which top? 
[18]Good. 
[19]Hey! 
[20]Forgot your keys -- 
[21]No no.  Don't cry at the beginning of the date. 
[22]And don't be a shoulder for him to cry on either. 
[23]First you gotta tell me something. 
[24]Because I'm worried that you're putting your faith in this guy who, because of the way things are going, may not have an emotional marble in his head. 
[25]Guys are just different people when they're hanging onto the bottom rung. 
[26]Easy, hon, I was just looking for fun details -- 
[27]Coffee, Jerry? 
[28]You're doing the right thing. I mean, come on.  You need to start your life and he... he needs a warm body to cushion the fall. Check out exhibit A on the front lawn -- 
[29]If you fuck this up, I'll kill you.
dialogues.JERRY'S VOICE:
[1]Airight so this is the world and there are five billion people on it.  When I was a kid there were three.  It's hard to keep up. 
[2]That's better.  That's america. See, America still sets the tone for the world... 
[3]In Indiana -- Clark Hodd.  13. The best point guard in the country. Puberty hasn't been easy. 
[4]Becky Farling.  You'll see her in the next Olympics. 
[5]Seattle, Washington.  Dallas Malloy. Went to court to be allowed to box professionally. She's 16. 
[6]Art Stallings, Indio, California. Check out what pure joy looks like. 
[7]In Odessa, Texas, the great Frank Cushman.  Cush is 20. Quarterback, role model, my client. He'll probably go number one in the draft this year. 
[8]There's genius everywhere, but until they turn pro, it's like popcorn in the pan. Some pop... 
[9]...  some don't. 
[10]Now I'm the guy you don't usually see. I'm the one behind the scenes.  I'm the sports agent. 
[11]You know those photos where the new player holds up the team jersey and poses with the owner? 
[12]That's me on the left. 
[13]Inside that building, that's where I work.  Sports Management International. 
[14]Thirty-three out of shape agents guiding the careers of 2,120 of the most finely-tuned athletes alive... 
[15]... in this economy, sometimes emotions run a little high. 
[16]Lately, it's gotten worse. 
[17]Two nights later in Miami at our corporate conference, a breakthrough. Breakdown? Breakthrough. 
[18]It was the oddest, most unexpected thing.  I began writing what they call a Mission Statement for my company. You know -- a Mission Statement -- a suggestion for the future. 
[19]What started out as one page became twenty-five. Suddenly I was my father's son.  I was remembering the simple pleasures of this job, how I ended up here out of law school, the way a stadium sounds when one of my players performs well on the field... I was remembering even the words of the late Dicky Fox, the original sports agent, who said: 
[20]And suddenly it was all pretty clear. The answer was fewer clients.  Caring for them, caring for ourselves, and the games too. Starting our lives, really. 
[21]Hey, I'll be the first to admit it. What I was writing was somewhat "touchy feely." 
[22]I didn't care.  I had lost the ability to bullshit.  It was the me I'd always wanted to be. 
[23]I printed it up in the middle of the night, before I could re-think it. 
[24]I was 35.  I had started my life. 
[25]Now little do I know that my assistant. has assumed that I've now proposed. So she has gotten the lounge band to actually play "Here Comes The Bride" when we walk back in.
dialogues.RAY:
[1]Mama -- 
[2]What's wrong, mom? 
[3]One-two-three... swing. 
[4]One-two-three, swing. 
[5]One-two... 
[6]Yeah! 
[7]No. 
[8]I'm not your brother! 
[9]Hi. 
[10]And then my dad died and my mom took me to the zoo and I love the zoo. Do you hate the zoo or do you love the zoo? 
[11]Let's go the zoo. 
[12]Let's go right now.  Let's go to the zoo. 
[13]You said "fuck". 
[14]I won't tell. 
[15]I don't see any. 
[16]Funny... I better go to bed. 
[17]I wanna go too. 
[18]Hi Jerry! 
[19]Let's have Apple Jacks! 
[20]What's going on, Jerry? 
[21]Show me the animal, Jerry! 
[22]I'm scared.  What is it? 
[23]Whoa. 
[24]Me too. 
[25]Jerry, can I come in and watch t.v.?
dialogues.WOMAN:
[1]Monkeyface... monkeyface, listen... I'm not going to say it here.... no... 
[2]...  oh listen, I got you the perfect white shirt, at this out of the way place... no... quit trying to make me say it! 
[3]how about if I do it and don't say it... mmmm... see you soon... 
[4]What -- 
[5]You're with the sports people on the plane, right? 
[6]Bobbi Fallon.  BPI.  I'm producing the Coke commercials for the playoffs. 
[7]Can I just get a quick "man's" opinion from you on something? 
[8]And I can't say his name without laughing I want to eat him up. I want to say goodbye to every bad thought I ever had about relationships.  I mean, I crave this guy... and yet... why... why did I have that affair this weekend?  Does that mean I'm not in love with my boyfriend? 
[9]It's the death rattle of my singlehood, right? Because I finally see the white picket fence looming and I love it/hate it/love it/hate it/ love it... you're right, I'll know when I see him. Why is it so easy to talk with you?!  Tell me about your fiancee. 
[10]Tell me, and then you can sleep. 
[11]Oh, tell the story. 
[12]Gorgeous. 
[13]That's when you need to cement, and define define define. 
[14]To the pools? 
[15]Oh no -- 
[16]How sad -- 
[17]Jerry.  You two will be together forever. 
[18]Oh my God, you're right.  I know. He's not The One.  He's not the One.
dialogues.CUSH:
[1]Hey, Jerry, what's been going on? 
[2]Hell, I'll either surf or ski. I don't care. 
[3]Jerry.  Why does God sometimes reward the evil and punish the good? 
[4]I see what you're saying. 
[5]Thank ya. 
[6]Say what? 
[7]Me too, dude.  Especially that big old singin' Elvis Monkey.  That's just insanity, man. 
[8]Hey, what size are you? 
[9]Why don't you grab a couple pairs of them new Nikes by the door -- 
[10]God, you're like a dude. 
[11]"It's okay to eat fish, 'cause they Don't have any feelings... 
[12]"Something in the way.  Yeah." 
[13]"Ooooooo." 
[14]Reporters, Jerry.  They been callin' all night. 
[15]Talking and saying nothing, man, it's an art I have not mastered. 
[16]Hell, I'm already sick of me. I got "Cushlash." 
[17]I'm sorry, Jerry.
dialogues.MATT:
[1]You like a Bloody Beer, Jerry? Beer and tomato juice -- 
[2]We decided to stay with you. 
[3]Told myself -- if he shows up, we'll stick with him. 
[4]I want him to go number one in the draft, and I want him to play. 
[5]Denver is where he should be. 
[6]You know I don't do "contracts." But'cha do have my word, and it's stronger than oak. 
[7]Well, he's gotta go number one. 
[8]What happened to Denver? 
[9]I don't know, Jerry. 
[10]Not right now, Jerry. 
[11]Apparently, Denver wanted to deal with him instead of you. 
[12]Hey, I'm learning as I go. 
[13]I'm sorry, I -- 
[14]We signed an hour ago.  You were in the lobby with the black fella. 
[15]They say it's show "business," Jerry, not show friends.
dialogues.DOOLER:
[1]You hear those courtesy laughs, Jerry? There is a seething wrongness at the edges of this party. 
[2]This is fuckin Michael Jordan, man! They should be screaming. 
[3]Oh, that'll really help this party! Let's all talk business! 
[4]Sorry I yelled.  You have exquisite taste. 
[5]I like that guy. 
[6]They ain't laughing, man. Something's wrong. 
[7]Look, Rod, just get on the camel! 
[8]The sponsor wants a camel -- 
[9]Then you shouldn't have begged me to hire him.
dialogues.TEE PEE:
[1]Hello Jerry Maguire. 
[2]An African-American man running with a little ball, working for white owners and white agents. It's the iconography of rascism... ... but I woulda stayed at the bigger company. 
[3]That's why they cheer, you know. The white man sending the black man into battle... 
[4]He'd better not mess up on Monday Night Football. 
[5]What did I say?  He gets nervous for the t.v. games... it's not a secret. 
[6]He's gonna have nothing left for next season.  They're letting him kill himself. 
[7]What'd I say? 
[8]He should have kept his head tucked down. 
[9]I'm not putting him down, I just have a commitment to the truth.
dialogues.CHAD:
[1]The new playhouse rocks, Dotty. 
[2]Yeah, Dotty. You did. 
[3]Hey, man, tonight I'm going to teach Ray about jazz. 
[4]You know, you people have a jazz problem in this house. 
[5]Yeah, how'd it go with Sportboy? 
[6]Treat her right, man.  She's... 
[7]She's great.  And I know this is a little awkward, but I want you to use this. 
[8]This... is Miles Davis and John Coltrane. Stockholm.  1963... two masters of freedom, playing in a time before their art was corrupted by a zillion cocktail lounge performers who destroyed the legacy of the only American artform -- JAZZ.
